Some of the topics will be  the male and female gaze, the documenting and editing of the female madwoman  such as in the documentary “Grey Gardens”. We will look at the 1967 documentary  of the drag beauty pageant “The Queen”, where we will consider gender fluidity,  representation and costuming femininity. Other units will be on gossip, the  soap opera, hysteria, horror films, female masculinity, abjection,  objectification, anger, ambiguity and invisibility. Students will also be  able to concentrate on a particular subject for research. A midterm  presentation and final project with companion papers is required. Text books:  Feminism and Visual Culture Reader edited by Amelia Jones published by  Routledge,                                                                        Icon edited by  Amy Scholder published by Feminist Press, with essays on Mary Gaitskill,  Andrea Dworkin, Linda Lovelace, Kathy Acker, Aretha Franklin, and bell hooks.                                        **This course will  count toward general education requirements for TSOA students (Social Science)           Undergraduate Admissions Graduate Admissions Academic Services Student Life Financial Aid and Scholarships Career Development Counseling Services International Students Incoming Students Graduation Forms What is Special Programs? Ben Shahn’s New York: The Photography of Modern Times                      Ben Shahn’s New York:  The Photography of Modern Times     Edited by Deborah Martin Kao, Laura Katzman, and Jenna Webster     Published by Yale University Press, 2000     Softcover, 9 x 10 inches, 342 pages, with black-and-white and color illustrations     ISBN: 0-300-08315-7    $35.00                              Ben Shahn’s New York: The Photography of Modern Times includes four critical essays and illustrations in both duotone and full color. The essays place Shahn’s work in context, providing an interdisciplinary analysis of the artist’s images of race, social class, and urban street life during the Great Depression. The astounding images introduce contemporary viewers to the infamous speakeasies of Greenwich Village, the street orators of Union Square, and the produce merchants of the Lower East Side, confirming Shahn’s active participation in these “scenes of living theater,” as the artist’s first published photographs of the city were appropriately titled. These photographs inspired many of his most important paintings, and established a photographic aesthetic and working process that would characterize his art for decades.
